title: 108_hr3049
content: The "Student Testing Fairness Act of 2003" is the short title of the Act. It includes amendments regarding adequate yearly progress and assessments. The "Student Testing Fairness Act of 2003" includes amendments to continuous growth models, averaging procedures, and adequate yearly progress by group and subject in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 focus on the performance of specific student groups in academic subjects. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 require multiple measures of student academic achievement, including specific focus on particular student groups in academic subjects. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 now include various measures of academic achievement, such as State report card indicators, performance index scores, student drop-out rates, and individual student achievement gains over time, broken down by student groups. Cut scores in the Act now consider the continuum of children's achievement levels. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to include measures of academic achievement like State report card indicators, performance index scores, and student achievement gains over time. The Act now considers the continuum of children's achievement levels within advanced, proficient, and basic levels. Amendments also remove the first score requirement for students taking assessments multiple times. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to include measures of academic achievement like State report card indicators, performance index scores, and student achievement gains over time. The Act now considers the continuum of children's achievement levels within advanced, proficient, and basic levels. Amendments also limit transfer options and supplemental services to students from failing groups. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to include measures of academic achievement aligned with challenging academic content. Amendments also limit transfer options and supplemental services to students from failing groups. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to include measures of academic achievement aligned with challenging academic content, including assessing students with disabilities. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 has been amended to include assessing students with disabilities whose academic level is below their enrolled grade using state assessments. Students with limited English proficiency may have their progress measured differently under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, allowing states to define adequate yearly progress for this group of students. Under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, students with limited English proficiency may have their progress measured differently to avoid distortion in measurement due to new arrivals. Amendments include excluding students with limited English proficiency who have resided in the US for less than 3 years. Amendment allows states to set a higher minimum number of students with disabilities for reliable data under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
